I apologize for the confusion. While the training of an aide-de-camp may vary between branches of the military, it can be difficult to provide detailed information on these differences. 

That being said, here are some further details on the training of ADCs in different branches of the military:

1. Army: Army officers selected for ADC duty undergo a selection process and attend a specialized course at the US Army Command and General Staff College (CGSC). They have to complete a two-year tour as a company-grade officer before they are eligible for selection. Once selected, they attend a six-week ADC course at the CGSC where they learn about military history, leadership, communication skills, protocol, and other important topics. They also receive specialized training in handling classified information, personal security, tactical operations, and firearms safety.

2. Marine Corps: Marine Corps officers who are selected for ADC duty attend the Basic Communications Officer Course (BCOC) at Marine Air Ground Combat Center Twentynine Palms. This course covers topics such as military communications, tactical operations, military customs and courtesies, and protocol. After completing the BCOC, officers receive specialized training in protocol and are assigned to their duties as ADCs.

3. Navy: ADCs in the Navy are typically experienced officers who have completed a rigorous selection process. Once selected, they attend the Naval Postgraduate School's Executive Master of Business Administration Program. They also receive specialized training in protocol, etiquette, and other important topics related to their duties as ADCs.

4. Air Force: Air Force officers who serve as ADCs are typically selected based on their leadership abilities and communication skills. They attend the Air Force Academy or the Air War College, and they receive instruction in protocol and diplomatic etiquette. They are also required to maintain a thorough understanding of the Air Force chain of command and other important aspects of the service.

Overall, while there may be some differences in the specific courses and training programs that ADCs in different branches undergo, the core training elements are similar. Officers selected for ADC duty typically receive training in communication, leadership, protocol, and other important skills that are essential for their duties as personal assistants to high-ranking officers.
